title: Individual session check functions
text: check_globalenv_objects() function performs session check roughly analogous one implicitly performed traditional method including rm(list=ls()) top script. inspects contents global environment using ls(), instead removing variables detected way, triggers warning order prompt user take appropriate action. present variables global environment detected ls(), environment considered clean nothing happens check_globalenv_objects() called: add variables global environment, warning triggered: output indicates script detected visible_1 visible_2 global environment, issues warning suggest R session may contaminated. allow_globalenv_objects argument used customize behavior check. takes character vector input, used “allow list”. variable name listed argument trigger action. special case: allow_globalenv_objects = NULL apply rule ls() uses listing contents global environment: variables start . ignored, trigger action. desired behavior detect variables global environment regardless name, set allow_globalenv_objects = "": time check detects .hidden_1 variable .Random.seed variable. see little detail, can convert result data frame: coercion permitted check functions, always returns data frame three columns: type column specifies name check performed, entity column specifies entity detected, status flag indicating whether entity trigger action. example , see “hidden” variables always detected, default status = FALSE accordingly trigger warnings, errors, messages.
code: check_globalenv_objects() visible_1 <- "this will get detected" visible_2 <- "so will this" .hidden_1 <- "but this will not"  check_globalenv_objects() #> Warning: Objects in global environment: visible_1, visible_2 check_globalenv_objects(allow_globalenv_objects = "") #> Warning: Objects in global environment: .hidden_1, .Random.seed, visible_1, #> visible_2 as.data.frame(check_globalenv_objects(action = "none")) #>        type       entity status #> 1 globalenv    .hidden_1  FALSE #> 2 globalenv .Random.seed  FALSE #> 3 globalenv    visible_1   TRUE #> 4 globalenv    visible_2   TRUE

title: Individual session check functions
text: role check_attached_packages() inspect search path see packages attached: warning notes addition base R packages (always ignored), sessioncheck package attached. see little explicitly, can coerce output data frame: output, can see several base R packages attached search path, listed status = FALSE therefore trigger warning. However, sessioncheck attached via call library() earlier document, detected, triggers warning. user can customize packages permitted, using allow_attached_packages argument. example, choose whitelist sessioncheck, illustrated example : done , warning longer triggered.
code: check_attached_packages() #> Warning: Attached packages: sessioncheck as.data.frame(check_attached_packages()) #> Warning: Attached packages: sessioncheck #>      type       entity status #> 1 package sessioncheck   TRUE #> 2 package        stats  FALSE #> 3 package     graphics  FALSE #> 4 package    grDevices  FALSE #> 5 package        utils  FALSE #> 6 package     datasets  FALSE #> 7 package      methods  FALSE #> 8 package         base  FALSE check_attached_packages(allow_attached_packages = "sessioncheck")

title: Individual session check functions
text: check_attached_environments() function complementary check_attached_packages(). functions inspect state R search path, look different things: check_attached_packages() looks package environments search path, usually added via library() require(). ignores non-package environments. check_attached_environments() looks non-package environments search path, usually added via attach(). ignores package environments. check functions, called clean R session check_attached_environments() nothing: mean environments detected. Coercing result data frame shows various package environments detected (ignored), global environment detected (ignored), two “special” environments detected ignored: present, four environments (besides packages global environment) whitelisted default, namely "tools:rstudio", "tools:positron", "tools:callr", "Autoloads". user prefer trigger action, allowed_attached_environments argument can used manually specify names allowed non-package environments: warning now triggered "Autoloads" whitelisted, "tools:callr" .
code: check_attached_environments() as.data.frame(check_attached_environments()) #>          type               entity status #> 1  attachment           .GlobalEnv  FALSE #> 2  attachment package:sessioncheck  FALSE #> 3  attachment        package:stats  FALSE #> 4  attachment     package:graphics  FALSE #> 5  attachment    package:grDevices  FALSE #> 6  attachment        package:utils  FALSE #> 7  attachment     package:datasets  FALSE #> 8  attachment      package:methods  FALSE #> 9  attachment            Autoloads  FALSE #> 10 attachment          tools:callr  FALSE #> 11 attachment         package:base  FALSE check_attached_environments(allow_attached_environments = "Autoloads") #> Warning: Attached environments: tools:callr

title: Individual session check functions
text: understand result, important recall current document rendered using pkgdown, consequence pkgdown dependencies appear loaded namespaces even though none attached search path. see little detail, can coerce result data frame: Notice namespaces associated base R listed (e.g., "base", “stats”, etc) always status = FALSE: namespaces never trigger warning/error/message. Similarly "sessioncheck" namespace never triggers action, since namespace must loaded order package used. packages involved rendering document listed status = TRUE. permit namespaces loaded without triggering action, use allow_loaded_namespaces argument: whitelisted namespaces, check now passes warning longer triggered.
code: check_loaded_namespaces() #> Warning: Loaded namespaces: digest, desc, R6, fastmap, and 19 more as.data.frame(check_loaded_namespaces(action = "none")) #>         type       entity status #> 1  namespace       digest   TRUE #> 2  namespace      methods  FALSE #> 3  namespace         desc   TRUE #> 4  namespace           R6   TRUE #> 5  namespace      fastmap   TRUE #> 6  namespace         xfun   TRUE #> 7  namespace       cachem   TRUE #> 8  namespace sessioncheck  FALSE #> 9  namespace        knitr   TRUE #> 10 namespace    htmltools   TRUE #> 11 namespace    rmarkdown   TRUE #> 12 namespace    lifecycle   TRUE #> 13 namespace        utils  FALSE #> 14 namespace          cli   TRUE #> 15 namespace         sass   TRUE #> 16 namespace      pkgdown   TRUE #> 17 namespace     graphics  FALSE #> 18 namespace  textshaping   TRUE #> 19 namespace    jquerylib   TRUE #> 20 namespace    grDevices  FALSE #> 21 namespace  systemfonts   TRUE #> 22 namespace        stats  FALSE #> 23 namespace     compiler  FALSE #> 24 namespace         base  FALSE #> 25 namespace        tools  FALSE #> 26 namespace         ragg   TRUE #> 27 namespace        bslib   TRUE #> 28 namespace     evaluate   TRUE #> 29 namespace         yaml   TRUE #> 30 namespace     jsonlite   TRUE #> 31 namespace        rlang   TRUE #> 32 namespace           fs   TRUE #> 33 namespace     datasets  FALSE check_loaded_namespaces(   allow_loaded_namespaces = c(     "digest", "desc", "R6", "fastmap", "xfun", "cachem",     "knitr", "htmltools", "rmarkdown", "lifecycle", "cli",     "sass", "pkgdown", "textshaping", "jquerylib",      "systemfonts", "ragg", "bslib", "evaluate", "yaml",     "jsonlite", "rlang", "fs", "htmlwidgets"   ) )

title: S3 classes and methods
text: Internally, sessioncheck_status object named list two components: status component named logical vector names correspond detected entities, values indicate whether action triggered entity. intended roughly analogous “exit status”: FALSE corresponds exit status zero actions triggered, TRUE non-zero exist status actions can taken. type component string indicating check function create status object. illustrated : format() print() methods sessioncheck_status object produce text displayed user message, warning, error: convenience, .data.frame() method also supplied:
code: unclass(pkg_status) #> $status #> sessioncheck        stats     graphics    grDevices        utils     datasets  #>         TRUE        FALSE        FALSE        FALSE        FALSE        FALSE  #>      methods         base  #>        FALSE        FALSE  #>  #> $type #> [1] "package" print(pkg_status) #> Attached packages: sessioncheck as.data.frame(pkg_status) #>      type       entity status #> 1 package sessioncheck   TRUE #> 2 package        stats  FALSE #> 3 package     graphics  FALSE #> 4 package    grDevices  FALSE #> 5 package        utils  FALSE #> 6 package     datasets  FALSE #> 7 package      methods  FALSE #> 8 package         base  FALSE

title: S3 classes and methods
text: sessioncheck() function can call multiple checks, data structure returns slightly different. illustrated named list sessioncheck_status objects: , format() print() methods used construct text displayed user: Similarly, .data.frame() method provided convenience:
code: lapply(session_check, unclass) #> $globalenv #> $globalenv$status #> .Random.seed   obj_status   pkg_status  #>        FALSE         TRUE         TRUE  #>  #> $globalenv$type #> [1] "globalenv" #>  #>  #> $packages #> $packages$status #> sessioncheck        stats     graphics    grDevices        utils     datasets  #>         TRUE        FALSE        FALSE        FALSE        FALSE        FALSE  #>      methods         base  #>        FALSE        FALSE  #>  #> $packages$type #> [1] "package" #>  #>  #> $attachments #> $attachments$status #>           .GlobalEnv package:sessioncheck        package:stats  #>                FALSE                FALSE                FALSE  #>     package:graphics    package:grDevices        package:utils  #>                FALSE                FALSE                FALSE  #>     package:datasets      package:methods            Autoloads  #>                FALSE                FALSE                FALSE  #>          tools:callr         package:base  #>                FALSE                FALSE  #>  #> $attachments$type #> [1] "attachment" print(session_check) #> Session check results: #> - Objects in global environment: obj_status, pkg_status #> - Attached packages: sessioncheck #> - Attached environments: [no issues detected] as.data.frame(session_check) #>          type               entity status #> 1   globalenv         .Random.seed  FALSE #> 2   globalenv           obj_status   TRUE #> 3   globalenv           pkg_status   TRUE #> 4     package         sessioncheck   TRUE #> 5     package                stats  FALSE #> 6     package             graphics  FALSE #> 7     package            grDevices  FALSE #> 8     package                utils  FALSE #> 9     package             datasets  FALSE #> 10    package              methods  FALSE #> 11    package                 base  FALSE #> 12 attachment           .GlobalEnv  FALSE #> 13 attachment package:sessioncheck  FALSE #> 14 attachment        package:stats  FALSE #> 15 attachment     package:graphics  FALSE #> 16 attachment    package:grDevices  FALSE #> 17 attachment        package:utils  FALSE #> 18 attachment     package:datasets  FALSE #> 19 attachment      package:methods  FALSE #> 20 attachment            Autoloads  FALSE #> 21 attachment          tools:callr  FALSE #> 22 attachment         package:base  FALSE

However, work better using rm(list=ls()) moreover, cases script executed dirty R session due user previously executing code loads packages creates variables global environment, tends work fairly well practice.
code: sessioncheck::sessioncheck() visible_1 <- "this will get detected" visible_2 <- "so will this" .hidden_1 <- "but this will not"  sessioncheck::sessioncheck() #> Warning: Session check results: #> - Objects in global environment: visible_1, visible_2 #> - Attached packages: [no issues detected] #> - Attached environments: [no issues detected] sessioncheck::sessioncheck(action = "error") #> Error: #> ! Session check results: #> - Objects in global environment: visible_1, visible_2 #> - Attached packages: [no issues detected] #> - Attached environments: [no issues detected] require(knitr) # non-base packages are detected #> Loading required package: knitr require(stats) # base R packages are ignored attach(iris)   # attached data frames are detected  sessioncheck::sessioncheck() #> Warning: Session check results: #> - Objects in global environment: visible_1, visible_2 #> - Attached packages: knitr #> - Attached environments: iris

Instead, put line R script: executed clean R session function nothing, script continues run normally . However, session “contaminated” – specific interpretation means call session “contaminated” – produce error, prevent script running, prompt human user consider restarting R session. illustrate happens contaminated R session, ’ll things R users agree fit definition “contaminated” R environment: creating objects global environment, attaching packages environments search path. actions vary considerably riskiness. example , ’s quick risk assessment: Attaching packages. ’s possible attaching sessioncheck package library() might cause problems, risk varies lot depending package . ’ve tried design sessioncheck safely, likely specific command won’t problem. won’t always true, therefore script notify unexpected packages detects. case, part wouldn’t bother attaching package. typical use case package call sessioncheck::sessioncheck() , top script. normal course events wouldn’t writing library(sessioncheck) script, yes, user probably informed. ’s just politeness! Adding objects global environment. Adding my_data data frame variable global environment bad thing, practice ’re running script interactive context – thing data analysts lot, much software engineers – can quickly build lot “detritus”, bits pieces objects left behind code tried previously. time becomes big problem, ’s harder reason ’s going data. user definitely informed, real risks . Attaching (malicious!) environment search path. Attaching data sets using attach() considered extremely high-risk behavior R long time. creates chaos R session potential horrific outcomes high. example constructed deliberately malicious, attempt highlight just bad attach() can . script executes environment attach(my_data) previously executed, can longer rely R make sensible judgements arithmetic: face , R now believes 2 + 2 = 5. doesn’t actually believe . result happens prior call attach() ensures can longer rely shorthand assumes T == TRUE. Indeed: fact: ideal world R script never using T shorthand TRUE exposes code exactly problem, unfortunately massive amount old R code current use relies shortcut. risk real. Noting R session now contaminated three ways, can see happens sessioncheck() called contaminated environment: code placed top user script, script simply refuse run contaminated environment. produce error indicates checks performed, lists specific issues detected test. way comparison, consider happen traditional rm(list=ls()) approach employed. Executing code fix one three problems: global environment now clean, code relies T mean TRUE now break, rm() command detached malicious environment: Even though rm(list = ls()) invoked, R session safe, corrupt behavior script executes session. Importantly, notice sessioncheck() stricter rm() approach, still produces error: normal circumstances thing user – human – likely next restart R session, problems go away. intended way use sessioncheck. designed primarily analysts design code human---loop fashion. explicitly recommended production code situation R code executed without direct human oversight. text: Invisibly returns object class sessioncheck_sessioncheck.

title: Checks the overall status of the R session — sessioncheck
text: sessioncheck() allows user apply multiple session checks single function. following arguments recognised via ...: allow_globalenv_objects passed check_globalenv_objects() allow_attached_packages passed check_attached_packages() allow_attached_environments passed check_attached_environments() allow_loaded_namespaces passed check_loaded_namespaces() max_sessiontime passed check_sessiontime() required_options passed check_required_options() required_locale passed check_required_locale() required_sysenv passed check_required_sysenv() arguments ignored.

title: Checks the overall status of the R session — sessioncheck
code: sessioncheck(action = "message") #> Session check results: #> - Objects in global environment: [no issues detected] #> - Attached packages: sessioncheck #> - Attached environments: [no issues detected]
